Mayadevi c R. Nandini Devi a 1 * a Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division, Pune, 411008, India Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division Pune 411008 India Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division and b Physical and Materials Chemistry Division, Pune, 411008, India Physical and Materials Chemistry Division Pune 411008 India bPhysical and Materials Chemistry Division c Chemical Engineering Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Pune, 411008, India Chemical Engineering Division CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Pune 411008 India cChemical Engineering Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Pune 411008, India ⁎ Corresponding author at: Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune, 411008, India. Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Dr. Homi Bhabha Road Pune 411008 India 1 Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad-201002, India. Graphical abstract CO2 hydrogenation to methane, an important reaction strategically and also for value adding to CO2, is investigated on two different catalysts, Ru supported on alumina as well as titania to understand better low temperature activity of Ru/TiO2 catalyst. In-situ infrared studies are carried out in three different steps, viz., (i) CO2 adsorption on fully reduced catalyst (ii) reaction of these adsorbed species with gaseous H2 and (iii) under co-feed of CO2 and H2, at different temperatures. On Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, CO2 reacts with hydroxyls on the support surface to form carbonate and adsorbs reductively on metal as CO. Further reduction to formate and methyl species occurs on reaction with H. Small concentration of the reactive intermediate formyl forms only at high temperatures. Whereas, bare TiO2 itself seems capable of reductive adsorption of CO2 as formate indicating enhanced reducibility of titania based catalyst. Formyl groups are observed at low temperatures in Ru/TiO2 in step (ii), which further forms methyl and gaseous methane at much lower temperatures when compared to alumina catalyst. Highly reactive CO species loosely bound to metal-support interface observed at high temperatures, which is not present on Ru/Al2O3 catalyst also makes this catalyst superior. In comparison, linearly bound CO seen in alumina catalyst is not as reactive. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation In-situ infra red spectroscopy Ru/Al2O3 Ru/TiO2 1 Introduction Global CO2 emission is increasing in an alarming rate [1] and the world has woken up to the dire need of reducing CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere. Hence it is imperative to advance the processes involved in conversion of CO2 to useful chemicals in parallel to the efforts in CO2 storage [2]. Value addition to this harmful and waste gas is to be focused in this endeavour and CO2 hydrogenation is proposed as a process with high potential for environmentally benign conversions, since H2 can now be produced from renewable sources [3] or available as surplus in chemical industry. The useful products obtained from CO2 hydrogenation are CO, CH3OH, HCOOH and CH4 [4–7]; CO and HCOOH can be employed for further chemical production and CH3OH and CH4 can be used directly as fuels [8,9]. CO2 hydrogenation to methane, known as the Sabatier reaction, is important for closed loop CO2 cycling where CO2 from contained spaces are recycled to fuel for combustion. Most used catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation to methane are oxide supported metals like Ni, Ru, Rh, Pt, Pd, Co etc [10,11]. A range of oxides like Al2O3, TiO2 etc. [12] are employed as supports and support dependent activity variations are identified [13]. Based on in-situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy studies on alumina supported metal catalysts, two different mechanisms are proposed for CO2 hydrogenation; (i) through formate route [14] and (ii) by reduction to CO as intermediate. In the former, CO2 adsorbed on the support is converted to formate species on interaction with homolytically split H on the metal surface, which is further reduced to CO and subsequently to CH4 through various intermediate CH* species. In the second route, CO2 dissociates directly to adsorbed CO instead of a formate intermediate before further transformation to methane [15,16]. In applications of this reaction, lower temperature conversions are desired and this can be achieved by fine tuning the metal and support types and thereby metal-support interactions. Among the oxide supports, TiO2 is known to catalyse CO2 hydrogenation at much lower temperatures than conventionally used alumina. Motivation for this work arose from a need to understand this low temperature activity and to translate it further into successful catalytic systems. For this, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy studies are carried out on two different catalyst systems, 0.5 wt% Ru supported on gamma alumina and titania. The studies show that metal-support interaction and interface play an important role in enhancing the low temperature activity of titania based catalyst. Reactive intermediates like formyl group and CO bound to different sites are identified as crucial to the activity. Inherent reducibility of Ru/TiO2 also has assisted in attaining superior activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis Ru/Al2O3 was obtained from commercial sources (0.5 wt% Ru, Johnson Matthey) and 0.5 wt% Ru/TiO2(p-25) was prepared by wet impregnation. Appropriate amounts of precursor salt, Ruthenium (III) chloride hexahydrate, was dissolved in 30–40 mL of water and stirred with TiO2(p-25) for 2 h. Then water was removed by rotary evaporator, dried over night at 100 °C, calcined in air at 400 °C for 2 h with ramping rate 2 °C/min and reduced under a flow of H2 at 400 °C for 2 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) for both the samples was carried out in PANalytical X’pert Pro dual goniometer diffractometer working under 40 kV and 30 mA. The radiation used was Cu Kα (1.5418 Å) with a Ni filter and the data was collected in 2θ range of 10° to 90°using a flat holder in Bragg-Brentano geometry with 1° slit at the source and receiving sides. An X’celerator solid-state detector with scan step size 0.008356° was employed. FEI Tecnai F20 electron microscope operating at 200 kV was used for sample observation. Sample for TEM was prepared by evaporating a drop of catalyst dispersed in isopropanol on a C coated copper grid. The percentage of Ru was confirmed by ICP-OES (SpectroAcros, FHS-12) and the sample was dissolved in aqua regia before analysis. FTIR spectra were obtained with an infrared spectrometer (Bruker Tensor 27) equipped with MCT detector and MIR source (U-shaped silicon carbide piece). 2.3 In-situ IR Praying Mantis accessory provided by Harrick was used for in-situ experiments. The catalysts (0.5% Ru/Al2O3 and 0.5 Ru/TiO2(p-25)) were first reduced under H2 flow of 20 mL min−1for 2 h. After completion of the reduction process, samples were cooled slowly under N2 till desired temperatures (175, 200, 250 and 300 °C), and was kept under N2 flow for 25–30 min for removing the gaseous H2. Background was collected while passing N2(25 mL min−1). In the next step, CO2(5 mL min−1) was passed over the catalyst and data were collected every 3 min for 15 min. Then, H2 was passed (20 mLmin−1) over the catalysts and data collected every 3 min for 15 min. System was flushed again with N2 and reduced at 400 °C with H2 prior to passing the reaction mixture, CO2, H2 and N2 in a ratio of 1:4:5 (50 mL min−1) at each temperature. Further, data were collected in the same manner as earlier. 2.4 Catalytic activity testing Evaluation of catalytic activity was carried out in a vertical, down flow, fixed bed metal reactor placed inside the furnace. Both experiments were carried out under atmospheric pressure in the temperature range of 175–325 °C and the calcined catalysts (0.3cc) were loaded in a steel reactor tube (id-10 mm, od-12 mm and length 25 cm). The temperature of the catalyst bed was continuously monitored with the help of a Cr-Al thermocouple. Reduction was done at 400 °C for 2 h under H2 prior to passing the reaction feed (Total flow =70 mL/min; CO2:H2:N2 = 1:4:5 vol%) with a space velocity of 14,000 h−1. The gas flow was controlled by Brooks mass flow controllers and outlet of the reactor was directly connected to the GC with TCD detector and He was used as carrier gas. 3 Results 3.1 Synthesis and characterisation Two catalysts, 0.5 wt% Ru supported on gamma alumina and p-25 titania were selected for studying CO2 hydrogenation to methane. Elemental analysis by ICP-OES ascertained the metal concentrations present in the catalysts as 0.46 and 0.37% respectively. Preliminary characterisation and textural analysis of the catalysts indicated the presence of well dispersed Ru nanoparticles on the supports (Fig. 1 ). PXRD profiles of the samples did not show discernible peaks of Ru due to high dispersion of the metal particles. Similarly, separate particles of Ru could not be identified in TEM images of both the samples indicating similar ultra small particles sizes in both. The surface areas measured from N2 adsorption method and BET analysis of Ru/Al2O3 and Ru/TiO2 are 124 and 51 m2 g−1 respectively. 3.2 Catalytic activity CO2 hydrogenation activities of the catalysts were studied in a fixed bed reactor in down flow mode. The catalysts were reduced under a flow of H2 prior to the reaction for 2 h, forming the active Ru(0) nanoparticles. As expected, low temperature activity of Ru/TiO2 was higher than Ru/Al2O3; at temperatures from 175 °C to 325 °C, the CO2 conversion was found to be more than two fold enhanced. We anticipate a combined contribution of metal support interaction, support effect and reducibility towards this low temperature activity. In both the catalysts, selectivity to CH4 was found to be 100% (Fig. 2 ). 3.3 In-situ IR For further understanding this difference in catalytic activity, adsorbed species at various temperatures were identified by diffuse reflectance IR under different conditions. First, the catalysts were reduced in-situ under a flow of H2. Then CO2 was passed after flushing away the gaseous H2 and loosely bound H2 with N2(step 1). This was done to understand the species formed on the surface of the metal nanoparticles when homolytically cleaved and adsorbed H interacts with gaseous CO2 and CO2 adsorbed on the oxide surface. After that, H2 was passed over the catalysts again to follow the reduction pathways of the adsorbed COx species (step 2). Finally, the catalysts were treated to attain their original state and then a mixture of CO2 and H2 in the stoichiometry of 1:4 was allowed contact, simulating actual reaction conditions (step 3). This was repeated for temperatures 175, 200, 250 and 300 °C. Spectra were collected every 3 min for 15 min, however, no substantial variation in peak intensities was observed within that time limit. To evaluate the adsorbed species on bare oxides without Ru, the same experiments were carried out with Al2O3 and p-25 powders. Relevant IR peak positions and the corresponding modes of CO and CO2 adsorption on metals and oxides are tabulated in Table 1 . At 175 °C (Fig. 3 , panel A), we observe carbonate species (symmetric stretching of O-C–O and C–O at 1435 and 1652 cm−1 respectively) [17,18] in step1 (trace a), ie., on CO2 interaction with adsorbed H on the metal surface. On passing H2 (trace b), the carbonate peak intensities are reduced and small amount of formate is formed vis-à-vis peaks at 1372, 1393, 1591 and 2903 cm−1 [19,20]. A drastic increase in CO concentration is observed, as evident from the peaks in the range 1850 to 2100 cm−1 [21–24] corresponding to the vibrational modes of metal adsorbed CO. In the gas phase, CO is identified by a peak at 2143 cm−1 [25,26]. A bathochromic shift of this peak to lower wavenumbers indicates backdonation from the metal to CO antibonding orbitals on adsorption [27]. Peaks in the range of ∼1850 cm-1 are attributed to CO of formyl group and those at ∼ 2000 cm-1 and above to linearly adsorbed CO on various metal and partially oxidised metal surfaces [28]. In CO2+H2 mixture (trace c), however, formate becomes predominant than CO along with other less intense peaks corresponding to carbonate. A corresponding increase in CHx peaks (at 3002 and 3016 cm-1 ascribed to C–H of CHx and methane respectively [29–31] may suggest that adsorbed CO is hydrogenated rapidly to CHx species. At 200 °C (panel B), very similar adsorption patterns are observed in terms of the presence of carbonate, CO and formate species. On reaction with the gas mixture (CO2+H2), formation of CHx species and gaseous methane through fine structure is very visible. However, on further increasing the temperature to 250 °C (panel C), discernible differences especially in CO adsorption features, emerge. Firstly, linearly adsorbed CO mode is observed in step 1, indicating CO2 reduction on reduced Ru metal surfaces. In addition, reaction of adsorbed species (probably both carbonate and CO) with gaseous H2 in step 2, leads to the formation of formyl group at 1857 cm-1 [32,33] and another mode of linearly adsorbed CO at 1972 cm-1. However, the formyl group is absent in a co-feed of CO2 and H2. At 300 °C also, we observe similar behaviour but with a drastic reduction in the concentration of formate species. Interestingly, at higher temperatures, adsorbed CHx species disappear and gaseous methane increases. In comparison, on pristine Al2O3, even at 300 °C, only bands corresponding to carbonates due to the reaction of CO2 with the hydroxyl groups present on the surface of alumina (1228, 1440 and 1647 cm-1) are observed and not those of the reduced species (Fig.S2 ESI). This was also observed on passing the reaction mixture. It is interesting to note that the overall spectral features and the evolution of species on bare TiO2 seem different from that on alumina. On bare TiO2 (Fig.S3 ESI), CO2 adsorption clearly occurs through formate intermediate as understood by the peaks at 1373 & 1539 cm−1 [34–36]. On passing H2, carbonates react to form methane which can be identified by peaks in the region ∼3000 cm−1. Formate species also seem to react but not to the extent of carbonate. Here, adsorbed water (peak at ∼1620 cm−1) is also visible. When the reaction mixture is passed, we observe carbonate, formate and water species adsorbed on the surface. Fig. 4 displays the in-situ IR spectra of 0.5%Ru/TiO2(p-25) under the same conditions as that presented for Ru/Al2O3 catalyst earlier. At 175 °C (panel A, trace a), CO2 interacts differently with the catalyst surface when compared to Ru/Al2O3, the main difference being the presence of formate species as evident from the peaks at 1372 and 1538 cm−1, corresponding to symmetric and asymmetric −COO stretch. Presence of formate species can also be concluded from the peak at 2880 cm-1 [37,38] corresponding to symmetric mode. In addition, we observe the presence of carbonate at 1424 cm−1 [39] and formyl group (at 1867 cm−1) [40] on Ru surface. It is interesting that these species are not present in the case of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst at this temperature. On reaction of these adsorbed species with H in the second step (trace b), all CO2 adsorbed species vanish and very small peaks corresponding to gaseous CH4 and linearly adsorbed CO appear. On passing the reaction mixture over the catalyst in step 3 (trace c), formate and linearly adsorbed CO species predominate along with adsorbed CHx and gaseous CH4 even at such low temperatures. The broad and intense background in the 1400-1700 cm−1 frequency range observed in the spectra possibly arises from the OH bend of adsorbed water. Such an effect as well as dip in the baseline can be caused by reflectivity of TiO2 [41]. Similar behaviour was observed at 200 °C also (panel B), however, drastic variations occur from 250 °C onwards. At higher temperatures, most of the carbonate and formate features become dormant and new adsorbed species related to CO, viz., peak at 2065 cm−1, emerge in step 1 at 250 °C. This can be attributed to very loosely bound CO on interface sites. Most importantly, small concentrations of gaseous CO can be identified (at 2143 cm−1) when only CO2 is passed over the catalyst. At 300 °C, we also observe coexistence of CO adsorbed on Ru(0) as well as Ruδ + at 2016 [42] and 1991 cm−1 [43] along with the high frequency peak now shifted to 2079 cm−1. A new peak at 1624 cm−1 [44,45] is observed at high temperatures, which cannot be conclusively assigned to, even though it is reported to represent water adsorption modes. Further, CO2 temperature programmed desorption suggests lower temperature desorption in case of Ru/TiO2 catalyst and similar tendency is observed in temperature programmed reduction also (Fig.S4, ESI). 4 Discussion From activity profiles of both the catalysts, it is clear that Ru/TiO2 has better low temperature activity for CO2 hydrogenation to methane. In case of Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, in-situ IR studies indicate that reaction proceeds through a pathway with the steps, carbonate→formate→ CO→CHx at lower temperatures with the last step being negligible. Direct CO2 adsorption-reduction on metal surface leads to CO formation only at higher temperatures (>200 °C), indicating that metal surface is activated only at high temperatures in case of alumina as support. This may also point to less support-metal interaction for this catalyst. As temperature increases, CO2 adsorption-reduction to various CO species on metal surface also increases. When CO is adsorbed on Ru metal surfaces, the peaks are assigned in the region of 1990-2000 cm−1. Gaseous CO has stretching frequency at 2143 cm−1, which is red shifted due to backdonation of electrons from Ru metal to the antibonding orbitals of CO. When backbonding is reduced, due to partial charge on Ru, CO peak will shift to higher frequencies (stronger bonds). When CO2 is reductively adsorbed on Ru, the metal surface gets partially oxidised by the dissociated O atom. We attribute the peak at 2016-2022 cm−1 to CO adsorbed on Ru atoms surrounded by Ruδ +. On passing H2, this surface gets more electron dense by converting part of CO to formyl as well as O to OH. In addition, peaks in the range 1950-2000 cm−1are attributed to CO adsorbed on such a surface. Methane is not seen in the second step at any temperature, which indicates that carbonate or linear CO does not directly form methane. The fact that formyl as well as CO adsorbed on more reduced Ru is observed at high temperatures indicate that they are highly transient in nature, evident from their absence in the third step (on using the reaction mixtures). It is possible that formate species also contributes to the formation of formyl groups. CO species also seem to originate from reductively adsorbed CO2 on the metal. It can be concluded that, when there is a constant supply of CO2 in the feed, CO2 reduction on Ru(0) surface predominates and dissociated H2 reacts to form formyl group and further to CHx. In case of Ru/TiO2 catalyst, we see a major difference in the species emerging at low temperature. Bare titania seems to have the capability to reductively adsorb CO2 as formate. Along with that, Ru/TiO2 seems to be capable of forming formyl groups at temperatures as low as 175 °C. We also see presence of gaseous methane in the second step at low temperatures indicating that the intermediates formed upon CO2 adsorption on titania catalyst react with H to form methane. At higher temperatures, the reactive species seen are entirely different from that of alumina based catalyst. The blue shift of stretching frequencies of the adsorbed CO species indicate that adsorption site may be Ti(4− δ )+ present in the metal-support interfaces. CO adsorbed on Ti4+ is reported to be observed at 2192-2209 cm-1 and on Ti3+ to be 2131 cm-1 [46]. Even though we do not have any evidence of presence of Ti3+ by XPS (Fig.S5 ESI), presence of reduced Ti species vis-à-vis Ru-O-Ti interfaces cannot be ruled out as evident from the presence of adsorbed CO with stretching frequencies of 2065 and 2079 cm-1. Moreover, these loosely bound CO species vanish whereas linearly bound CO seems to be retained on the surface showing them to be more reactive. To understand the stability of the adsorption of the carbonate, formate and CO, spectra were collected while flushing the system with N2 after passing CO2 at 300 °C (Figure S6, ESI). It seems that formyl species is strongly adsorbed on Ru/Al2O3 surface rather than on Ru/TiO2. We do not anticipate any Ru which is more oxidised than the Ruδ + which is observed in step 1, since the reaction conditions are highly reducing. Hence these peaks are not attributed to CO adsorbed on oxidised Ru. XPS studies of the spent catalysts also show that Ruδ + is observed only in Ru/TiO2 and not in Ru/Al2O3 (Figure S7, ESI). TPR and TPD observations like enhanced reducibility and ease of CO2 desorption also supports low temperature activation of Ru/TiO2 catalyst. O vacancies on TiO2 surface can also facilitate CO2 adsorption advantageously [47]. Based on these observations, we propose a probable mechanistic insight into the low temperature activity of TiO2 based catalyst as due to its ability to form reactive intermediates at lower temperatures as presented in Scheme 1 . In pre-reduced Ru/Al2O3, CO2 adsorbs as carbonate and CO on support and metal respectively. These species are reduced further to formate and low concentration of formyl groups which may be subsequently reduced to methane. Whereas in Ru/TiO2, CO2 adsorption itself leads to the formation of formate and formyl species, indicating more reducing nature of this catalyst, which further forms methane. 5 Conclusion Understanding the mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methane will assist in designing better catalysts for this important reaction. Among various catalysts reported, Ru/TiO2 exhibits enhanced activity at lower temperatures when compared to more conventional Ru/Al2O3. Extensive in-situ IR studies indicate this difference to have arisen from the variations in metal-support interactions and interface sites. In Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, at lower temperatures, CO2 adsorbs on oxide as carbonate which is reduced to formate and CO. Further reduction to CHx seems to be negligible. Here, support-metal interaction exists to a lesser extent since the metal surface seems to be activated only at higher temperatures. In a co-feed of CO2 and H2 as in real conditions, CO2 reduction on Ru(0) surface predominates. Formyl intermediate seems to be playing a crucial role in determining the activity of the catalysts. In Ru/TiO2 catalyst, formyl species are detected at temperatures as low as 175 °C. Bare TiO2 support is comparatively active in the formation of reduced species like formate than alumina. This also enhances its low temperature activity. At high temperatures, very new CO species evolve which are proposed to be adsorbed on partially reduced Ti4+ interface sites. These loosely bound CO species are much more reactive compared to linearly bound CO. This also leads to a 4–5 fold increase in catalytic activity of Ru/TiO2 at temperatures ≥250 °C in comparison to Ru/Al2O3. coredata.dc:description: CO2 hydrogenation to methane, an important reaction strategically and also for value adding to CO2, is investigated on two different catalysts, Ru supported on alumina as well as titania to understand better low temperature activity of Ru/TiO2 catalyst. In-situ infrared studies are carried out in three different steps, viz., (i) CO2 adsorption on fully reduced catalyst (ii) reaction of these adsorbed species with gaseous H2 and (iii) under co-feed of CO2 and H2, at different temperatures. On Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, CO2 reacts with hydroxyls on the support surface to form carbonate and adsorbs reductively on metal as CO. Further reduction to formate and methyl species occurs on reaction with H. Small concentration of the reactive intermediate formyl forms only at high temperatures. Whereas, bare TiO2 itself seems capable of reductive adsorption of CO2 as formate indicating enhanced reducibility of titania based catalyst. Formyl groups are observed at low temperatures in Ru/TiO2 in step (ii), which further forms methyl and gaseous methane at much lower temperatures when compared to alumina catalyst. Highly reactive CO species loosely bound to metal-support interface observed at high temperatures, which is not present on Ru/Al2O3 catalyst also makes this catalyst superior. In comparison, linearly bound CO seen in alumina catalyst is not as reactive.
coredata.dc:title: Variations in activity of Ru/TiO2 and Ru/Al2O3 catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation: An investigation by in-situ infrared spectroscopy studies
